chapter.title: Quick start
chapter.para: SUSE Enterprise Storage is a distributed storage system designed for scalability, reliability, and performance, which is based on the Ceph technology. The traditional way to run a Ceph cluster is setting up a dedicated cluster to provide block, file, and object storage to a variety of clients.

Rook manages Ceph as a containerized application on Kubernetes and allows a hyper-converged setup, in which a single Kubernetes cluster runs applications and storage together. The primary purpose of SUSE Enterprise Storage deployed with Rook is to provide storage to other applications running in the Kubernetes cluster. This can be block, file, or object storage.
This chapter describes how to quickly deploy containerized SUSE Enterprise Storage 7 on top of a SUSE CaaS Platform 4.5 Kubernetes cluster.

sect1.title: Recommended hardware specifications
sect1.para:
For SUSE Enterprise Storage deployed with Rook, the minimal configuration is preliminary, we will update it based on real customer needs.
LGHP 2020-10-07: Should we at least link to the CaaSP system requirements?
For the purpose of this document, consider the following minimum configuration:

listitem.para: A highly available Kubernetes cluster with 3 master nodes
Four physical Kubernetes worker nodes, each with two OSD disks and 5GB of RAM per OSD disk
Allow additional 4GB of RAM per additional daemon deployed on a node
Dual-10 Gb ethernet as bonded network
If you are running a hyper-converged infrastructure (HCI), ensure you add any additional requirements for your workloads.

sect1.title: Prerequisites
sect1.para: Ensure the following prerequisites are met before continuing with this quickstart guide:

listitem.para: Installation of SUSE CaaS Platform 4.5. See the SUSE CaaS Platform documentation for more details on how to install: .
Ensure ceph-csi (and required sidecars) are running in your Kubernetes cluster.
Installation of the LVM2 package on the host where the OSDs are running.
Ensure you have one of the following storage options to configure Ceph properly:
Raw devices (no partitions or formatted file systems)
Ensure the SUSE CaaS Platform 4.5 repository is enabled for the installation of Helm 3.

step.para: You need to apply Labels to your Kubernetes nodes before deploying your Ceph cluster. The key node-rol.rook-ceph/cluster accepts one of the following values:
Run the following the get the names of your cluster's nodes:
On the node you want to Label, run the following:
step.screen: kubectl@adm > kubectl label nodes node-name label-key=label-value
step.para: For example:
step.screen: kubectl@adm > kubectl label node k8s-worker-node-1 node-role.rook-ceph/cluster=any

Next, you need to apply the cluster.yaml to your Kubernetes cluster. The default cluster.yaml can be applied as is without any additional services or requirements from a Helm chart.
To apply the default Helm chart to your Kubernetes cluster, run the following command:
step.screen: tux > helm -n rook-ceph install rook-ceph ./rook-ceph/ -f myvalues.yaml

sect1.title: Configuring the Ceph cluster
sect1.para: You can have two types of integration with your SUSE Enterprise Storage intregrated cluster. These types are: CephFS or RADOS Block Device (RBD).
Before you start the SUSE CaaS Platform and SUSE Enterprise Storage integration, ensure you have met the following prerequisites:

listitem.para: The SUSE CaaS Platform cluster must have ceph-common and xfsprogs installed on all nodes. You can check this by running the rpm -q ceph-common command or the rpm -q xfsprogs command.
That the SUSE Enterprise Storage cluster has a pool with a RBD device or CephFS enabled.
